title: brexit latest no deal irish border article 50
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis:&nbspAs a compromise on the Irish border edges&nbspcloser, Europe Correspondent Jon Stone looks at what happens nextClick to followIndy PoliticsTailbacks: A vision of a no-deal Brexit? There may yet be a Brexit agreement on the Irish border. The latest whispers out of meetings in Brussels are that the EU is preparing to offer a compromise solution on the so-called “backstop”. Whether it will be enough for the UK remains to be seen.But let’s suppose it is, and a withdrawal agreement is signed. Does that prevent a no deal? Not exactly.There are two things that could still cause a no-deal Brexit. Both bring a huge degree of uncertainty.EU plans compromise on customs union to solve Irish borderThe first is the parliamentary vote. Theresa May, you may remember, has no majority in the House of Commons and needs help. How the DUP, Labour, and Conservative Eurosceptics&nbspvote will determine whether a deal passes parliament, even if it has been agreed between&nbspnegotiators.The second uncertainty is over the future trading relationship. An outline of this was supposed to have been agreed by now, but the timetable has slipped because of a lack of progress on Northern Ireland, which the EU insists must be dealt with first.&nbspIt is not widely understood that UK law states that this outline of the future relationship has to be presented to MPs before any vote on the withdrawal deal. But it is simply not clear how this will be possible.&nbspTheresa May’s Chequers plan has been dismissed, and she has rejected the EU’s options of a loose free trade agreement or Norway-style single market participation. Negotiations are practically at square one for this, with practically no time left.It is widely claimed that any document will have to be a fudge. But the EU said at the Salzburg summit that any outline must be specific – not just a list of vague aspirations.Brexit talks ‘close to a deal’ says DUP leader Arlene FosterGovernment urged to revive fishing for endangered tuna after BrexitArron Banks is hoping to become some kind of Brexit martyrUK construction dogged by Brexit uncertainty in OctoberHow agreement could be reached on anything substantial is unclear, and neither side looks able to back the other’s proposals. It’s possible the issue of the trading relationship could make a comeback and sink the whole thing.And yet, if we cannot sign a deal, Britain may still avoid heading over the cliff edge.&nbspThe government says emphatically it is prepared to go ahead with a no-deal Brexit, but the truth is the country is simply not prepared. The physical infrastructure needed is not in place and will take years to build, at ports, airports, and elsewhere.&nbspThere is certainly not a majority in the House of Commons for a no-deal, and the political damage to the government of going ahead with one far outweighs any benefit.However, there remains the option to revoke Article 50 – even temporarily – before March 29.&nbspEmpty supermarket shelves, grounded flights, and queues at ports are a prime minister’s worst nightmare. Desperation to avoid this at all costs means that a&nbsplast-minute government U-turn is more than just a possibility&nbsp– it’s likely.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? Christopher Desira warned that travellers should start gathering paperwork such as tax documentsTravellers and Roma gypsies have been warned about the risk of deportation after Brexit if they fail to possess the correct paperwork,&nbspamid fears of a&nbspWindrush-style&nbspcrackdown by the Home Office.Those at risk&nbsphave been urged to gather as many official documents as possible in case they are asked to prove their residency in the UK after the country leaves the EU.At the Traveller Movement national annual conference, community leaders discussed the difficulties many from the Roma and traveller communities may face proving they have lived in the UK for at least five years.Woman set to become UK's first Roma barrister on Brexit insecurityMany feared they could face the same threats of deportation as the Windrush Generation in the years after Brexit because of lack of official paperwork.Low levels of literacy, digital illiteracy, cost, lack of awareness of the implications of Brexit and deep distrust of state institutions such as the Home Office were all cited as barriers preventing travellers and Roma gypsies applying for settled status by the deadline of June 30 2021.Immigration lawyer Christopher Desira warned that travellers should start gathering paperwork such as tax documents, education certificates, bank statements or employment contracts if they do not have a passport in case they are asked to prove they have lived in the UK for at least five years.The Home Office is particularly worried about fraud, he said.He said that in an extreme scenario, travellers unable to prove their residency could be held indefinitely in a detention centre, despite having no country of origin other than the UK.Mr Desira said such an outcome was unlikely for British travelling communities but emphasised that life could become more difficult for anyone without a passport after Brexit.Created with Sketch.Britain before Brexit: East of England Show all I am charmed by the arrangement of their bodies and the shapes in which they are bonding. I realise the contemporary significance of the scene: the labyrinth - a complicated, irregular network of passages in which it is difficult to find one’s way - alongside the simplicity and closeness of human togetherness. In any complicated maze-like structure - Brexit included - it is important to remember that people and love and relationships are a vital part of the picture.Walking back into town from Leagrave High Street I notice two graffitied propaganda messages: ‘Free Gaza’ and ‘Beverly is a black cow’. Here are but two voices, I think, in the crazy cacophony of contemporary British discourse, of the British tongue, fractured as it is into accents, splintered by slangs, torn, in this case, into the libertarian and abusive, one dehumanising, one for freedom.University students hold a flash protest against the low pay of McDonald’s employees. They receive tuts, cheers, insults, whoops, raised eyebrows. People enter the restaurant in any case, unaware or uncaring that they have crossed a picket line.I went to look inside the Catholic Cathedral during Mass. I wanted to see the ritual and the practices, the people and their poses. There is a rich spectrum of visual dimensions to Catholic prayer that I first noticed when photographing in Poland. I’m attracted to its ambivalence: solemn and joyous lonely in dialogue desperate but determined solitary yet complete.Posters from the town’s glory days surround the Winter Gardens as it rusts and becomes overgrown. It seems like an intentional act to rekindle nostalgia in the face of disrepair, to balance the present with representations of the past.At the back of the central market hang three representations of conflict, side-by-side, connected, making sense in relation to one another. Only one message can be worn at any one time, but together they narrate a powerful image of modern Britain: a unified group, a club, an undefeated nation facing an existential threat from its enemies.People set up posts outside the train station, asking the town’s new arrivals for various things: religious missionaries seek attention and commitment a person sleeping rough asks for food and spare change. I’m interested in how this affects the visual experience of arriving in Luton and what the religious and the homeless look like when viewed in the same frame.A concoction of interests outside King’s College: a tourist desperately hailing lost members of the group a shopper takes a break from the high street a man sits to read a woman meditates with her identity concealed.A family emerges from the colours of Leagrave High Street. Twins sit and stare, identically, scrutinising me, like their father, perhaps. They are framed by rails of clothes. Mannequins exaggerate their life.A pop-up employment workshop opens for business in the town centre. The sign is heavily loaded with the values of modern Britain: one must aspire to achieve, earn, and live acquiring skills is akin to personal development the prioritisation of the ‘local’. A lady carrying water on a scooter - unconventionally, comically, skilfully - appears as a strange detail of everyday life passing such lofty visions.The Britannia Monument celebrates Horatio Nelson’s life. An acrobat fell from the top and died in 1863. It remains a mystery, a travesty for some, that Britannia - the monument’s embodiment of the nation - has her back to the sea. These days she turns her back on a single one-man tent too, a home, a shelter erected on the shore.This was the last scene I saw in the town. I was leaving. I thought of how child’s play, in its innocence and vitality, continues amidst our hunched, phone-tapping adolescence and adulthood.A couple and their dog relax by the Cathedral’s Labyrinth. which is an online process - was also a problem.Our work with (Roma communities) found that there was also a very low awareness of the need to apply to secure their position in the UK.Now they know there is this application, but it's £65 - many are on very low incomes and have very large families and it's just unfeasible.Then there is the language barrier - many speak some English but it's not the level needed to access this application.There are an estimated 300,000 Roma living in the UK.Ms Zawacki said women in Roma communities are particularly vulnerable as they may never have worked or been registered with an official organisation even if they have lived in the UK for decades as they would traditionally be looking after children.She said the same concerns applied to the elderly who may have been brought to the UK to be looked after or to look after children.Trust is also such a problem that those who came to the organisation for help are unwilling to answer an anonymous survey asking only Do you have a chip passport and Do you have £65 because of the questions' connection with immigration authorities.Asked if it was possible the UK could carry out mass deportations of Roma gypsies she said: The Home Office has given no clarity on what will happen to people who have their application refused apart from that they can apply again - story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsAverage wages also rose by 3.1 per cent year-on-year, the fastest rate since 2009Click to followThe IndependentThe US construction sector added 30,000 new jobs in OctoberThe US jobs market continued to surge in October, adding 250,000 new jobs.That figure, reported by the Bureau of Labor&nbspStatistics (BLS), was 60,000 higher than the 190,000 Wall Street analysts had pencilled in.It was also higher than the average monthly gain of 211,000 over the past year.General Motors says Trump’s tariffs could threaten US jobsAnd average wages rose by 3.1 per cent year-on-year, the fastest rate since 2009.The unemployment rate was unchanged at 3.7 per cent, the lowest rate since 1969.The dollar index spiked in the wake of the data, rising to 96.322. But the wider market reaction was more muted.“The US released the strongest employment report in over a decade today,” said Eric Norland of CME&nbspGroup.“These numbers should underpin both strong consumer spending as well as generate inflation fears.&nbspMoreover, the exceptionally strong employment numbers will give the Federal Reserve the ammunition that it needs to continue raising rates, despite objections from the White House.”&nbspThe US central bank raised interest rates to 1.75-2 per cent in September to cool what it sees as rising inflationary pressures.Projections by Fed’s policymakers signal&nbspone further quarter point rate hike later this year, followed by three in 2019 and another three in 2020.The BLS&nbspsaid the major October jobs gains were in healthcare (36,000), manufacturing (32,000), construction (30,000) and transportation (25,000).Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - It will serve as an opportunity for businesses to reach people, he said.WhatsApp update finally brings stickers to messaging appThe status feature is something like the stories tool that appears in Instagram and Facebook, as well as WhatsApp. It allows people to post updates that will appear to all of their friends, letting them share photos or text and then letting it disappear afterwards.WhatsApp has struggled to come up with ways to show its users ads: without a feed, like Instagram or Facebook, there are few places for them to be injected.When it dropped its subscription fee in 2016, the company posted a blog post making clear that ads would never interrupt your communication, further adding to the issues about how advertising could be shown within the app.But the status feature appears to have solved that problem, allowing WhatsApp to slide marketing posts in between updates from friends, like it does with Instagram stories.As well as serving as something like a feed, WhatsApp's status feature has quickly become a huge part of the app. It now has a huge number of users, and is more popular than many major apps like Snapchat.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: A source whom the former Prime Minister confided in disclosed Mr Cameron would not rule out a return to UK politics if a future Tory leader asked him to come back.The role Mr Cameron would assume is not entirely clear but the insider implied it could be Foreign Secretary.Speaking to The Sun, the source said: &ldquoDavid is dedicated to public service, and has often said he wouldn&rsquot rule out a public role one day, domestically or internationally.&ldquoBut he is only 52, and still a young man. story: ITV&rsquos Robert Peston said the Treasury had indeed negotiated a &ldquohigh-level agreement with Brussels on aspects of the future partnership just hours after the EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator blasted the same claims as &ldquomisleading.Michel Barnier took the unprecedented step on Wednesday of angrily tweeting about reports in the Times that the EU caved in to allow UK financial services continued access to the Brussels bloc after Britain&rsquos exit.This was followed by a furious statement by Downing Street who said the reports were speculation as Brexit talks are still ongoing.But writing in a blog last night, political journalist Mr Peston said: &ldquoIt&rsquos true that a few weeks ago, the Treasury over the course of a couple of days successfully negotiated some &lsquohigh level principles&rsquo for what the future access relationship might be for UK-based banks and other financial institutions to the EU's single market. story: EU nations say they will refuse to give the green light to a tariff-free customs deal with Britain unless European boats are allowed to fish in UK waters.The demand comes amid fears from the EU&rsquos remaining 27 states that Brussels accepting terms in Mrs May&rsquos Withdrawal Agreement could end up costing them the upper hand in trade negotiations.The Prime Minister is plotting to secure a UK-wide customs union as part of a backstop plan to stop a hard border in Ireland - a plan she turned to after the EU threatened to take control over Northern Ireland and coax it away from Great Britain, a move rejected by the DUP.But France, Denmark, the Netherlands, Spain, Belgium and Germany are spearheading a campaign to scoop access to the UK&rsquos waters, with eurocrats insisting &ldquoaccess to waters will remain a priority for EU nations during Brexit negotiations.Tory MP demands Royal Navy protects UK fishermen from French attacksScallop wars: British VICTORY as French fishing ban slapped down To make matters worse, Brussels has enraged Brexiteers by demanding continued access to UK waters for EU vessels will be part of a future trade deal.Brussels&rsquo guidelines read: &ldquoIn the overall context of the FTA, existing reciprocal access to fishing waters and resources should be maintained.Each member state will have a final say on the EU&rsquos trade deal with Britain.Anand Menon, from the UK in a Changing Europe think tank, told The Sun the issue &ldquomight get in the way for the withdrawal deal yet.Mrs May&rsquos Withdrawal Agreement could end up costing them the upper hand in trade negotiations (Image: )In September, a violent clash took place between UK fishermen and the French  (Image: SWNS)He said: &ldquoAt best it&rsquos a warning about what awaits us. At worst it&rsquos something that might get in the way during this negotiation itself.The issue of EU member states using UK waters and vice versa has plagued British fishermen throughout the year.In September, a violent clash took place between UK fishermen and the French who rammed boats into British vessels to stop them fishing in a harbour off the French coast which was rich with scallops.Rocks and smoke bombs were launched by more than 30 French vessels in a skirmish with a handful of British boats off the coast of Normandy.                &lsquoThey&rsquore sabotaging us&rsquo - UK and French fisherman face-off AGAIN                French fishermen could CLASH with British boats after BrexitThe so-called scallop wars were over access to stocks in the Baie de Seine grounds.National regulations let British ships fish there legally all year round, but French fishermen are banned from taking the molluscs between May 15 and October 1, to conserve stocks.

story: Paris struck a deal with the Republic of Ireland to fast-track its commercial drivers crossing the Channel from Dover to the French port.The agreement was made between Ireland&rsquos Foreign Minister Simon Coveney and his French counterpart Jean-Yves Le Drian on Wednesday.Mr Coveney said: &ldquoWe&rsquove had quite detailed discussions in terms of differentiating Irish trucks from British trucks. Under the right circumstances Irish trucks will not need to be inspected, whereas UK trucks may need to be inspected.But the deal has angered haulage firms in the UK, who have blasted the EU for an apparent attempt to punish and humiliate Britain over Brexit. story: The heated exchange started when a member of the audience asked the panel on the BBC flagship show if austerity was now over, which is what Chancellor Philip Hammond suggested during his Budget speech on Monday.Labour MP Andy McDonald rebutted &ldquoausterity is not over, arguing it will continue and &ldquothere is more to come.He told the audience: &ldquoWe had billions ripped out of social care, our schools are underfunded as they have had an 8 percent cut.&ldquoIt is an absolute outrage and austerity has not come to an end.                BBC Question Time LIVE: David Dimbleby hosts Andrea Jenkyns for debateBBC Presenter David Dimbleby then interrupted the Labour MP for Middlesborough to ask him why then Labour approved of the Conservative tax cuts for middle and high earners on Thursday.Mr McDonald explained &ldquothe threshold increase to &pound12,5000 gets to some of the poorest people and Labour said it quite clearly we will raise taxes for those above &pound80.0000.David Dimbleby interrupted him again to say he was &ldquododging the question.The Labour MP raised his voice to deny the claim, and so did Mr Dimbleby who pointed out: &ldquoI am asking you a simple thing!Labour MP Andy McDonald rebutted &ldquoausterity is not over, arguing it will continue  (Image: BBC) David Dimbleby angrily raised his voice at a Labour MP for dodging one of his questions (Image: BBC)The BBC presenter added: &ldquoWhy did you approve letting people who pay 40 percent tax pay not at &pound46,000 but not until they earn &pound50,000?&ldquoIn other words, not to pay 40 percent until they are earning 50 grand?&ldquoWhy did you go with that if your argument is that more money we can put into schools and all the other things the sooner austerity will end?Under Mr Hammond's Budget plans the personal allowance, which is the maximum amount someone can earn before paying tax, will rise to &pound12,500 from &pound11,850.                Tom Watson weight loss: Labour MP adds this to his morning coffee The Labour MP raised his voice to deny the claim, and so did Mr Dimbleby (Image: BBC)Under Mr Hammond's Budget plans the higher rate threshold will rise to &pound50,000  (Image: BBC)The higher rate threshold, the income at which someone becomes liable to pay the 40 percent tax rate, will rise to &pound50,000 from &pound46,350 at the same time.An analysis by the Resolution Foundation thinktank found that almost half the benefit of the policy would go to the top 10 percent of households.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell surprised many in his party by agreeing with Mr Hammond, claiming he did not want to take money out of people&rsquos pockets.

title: Brexit news UK EU Ireland border backstop concession Theresa May deal latest
story: EU negotiators are preparing to climbdown on the Prime Minister's demands for a UK-wide customs arrangement to be included in the withdrawal agreement to end the Irish backstop impasse.Allowing Britain to set out the terms of a UK-wide customs arrangement in the withdrawal treaty is a significant concession from Brussels.Diplomats hope their next offer could be enough to kickstart the stalled Brexit negotiations, which have seen little movement on the vexed issue on the Irish border.The Irish backstop, the mechanism to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland, remains the biggest obstruction for UK and EU officials to overcome in order to strike a deal.Mrs May has been absolute in her rejection of Brussels current backstop offer because it essentially cuts off Northern Ireland from Great Britain until a permeant solution is found.Under the current terms, Northern Ireland would remain in the bloc's customs union and its single market for goods, creating a border in the Irish Sea.But the compromise will allow the entire UK to form a customs arrangement with Brussels, with both parties applying a common external trade tariff on imports from outside the bloc and rules of origin.Northern Ireland would still remain in the full customs union but it would prevent the creation of a customs border in the Irish Sea.Brexit news: EU set to offer Theresa May UK-wide customs arrangement to fix Irish border (Image: )Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab still hasn't announced plans to visit Michel Barnier in Brussels (Image: )The plans would see this new compromise written into the withdrawal agreement, something the EU has been reluctant do in the past.Brussels has attempted to write-off a UK-wide customs arrangement for the backstop being included in the exit treaty because they see this as an issue for the future relationship.The offer is largely unchanged from terms rejected by Downing Street in October but allows Mrs May a watertight legal guarantee that a customs border in the Irish Sea will not be created.EU lawyers are currently attempting to establish whether the withdrawal agreement can facilitate a UK-wide customs union, that would be required until a future UK-EU trade agreement is signed.                Labour OUTRAGE as civil war rages on amid claims Corbyn would back May                Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling could &lsquohold gains&rsquo this weekendThe possibility of an extended transition period also remains on the table after the Prime Minister told counterparts she would consider it to avoid a Northern Ireland-specific backstop.Negotiations will continue to rumble on with Brussels waiting on Mrs May's next offer.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab still has no concrete plans to return to the Belgian capital to meet EU negotiator Michel Barnier.Mr Raab believes talks can be concluded within three weeks, which was revealed in a letter to the House of Common's Brexit committee.He told chairman Hilary Benn he would be available to give evidence when the withdrawal agreement is complete.The Brexit Secretary suggested November 21 as a possible date to give evidence, but promised to return &ldquowhen a deal is finalised.On Thursday, Ireland's foreign minister said Britain would have to make progress next week if a deal is to be possible for November.Simon Coveney said: If there is to be a breakthrough in November, then we need the negotiating teams to find a way forward in the next week or so.

story: Moment Thatcher savaged Remainer John Major for &lsquoputting head in fire'                MAJORITY of young Britons support Thatcher&rsquos legacy, study reveals In Amazon Prime documentary &ldquoMargaret Thatcher I will Not Undertake, her address is described as a landmark moment.&nbspThe narrator says: &ldquoHer Bruges speech in September 1988 began the process by which the Conservative Party, at one time largely pro-European, became predominantly eurosceptic.It came after Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, urged Britain&rsquos labour movement to embrace a &ldquouniquely European model of society and support a &ldquoplatform of guaranteed social rights.&nbspIn response, Thatcher said Europe should focus on competitiveness and deregulation while warning against a &ldquoEuropean super-state exercising a new dominance from Brussels.She said: &ldquoI want to see us work more closely on the things we can do better together than alone.&ldquoEurope is stronger when we do so, whether it be in trade, in defence or in our relations with the rest of the world.&ldquoBut working more closely together does not require power to be centralised in Brussels or decisions to be taken by an appointed bureaucracy.Her rebuke did not stop there, though.Margaret Thatcher delivered a fiery speech on Britain's relationship with Europe in 1988 (Image: )Margaret Thatcher compared the proposed EU to the Soviet Union  (Image: )Thatcher, who had been Prime Minister for nine years at the time, went on to make a bold Soviet Union comparison and argued that the financial reforms she introduced in the 1980s would be completely undermined should Britain adopt the European model.&nbspShe added: &ldquoIndeed, it is ironic that just when those countries such as the Soviet Union, which have tried to run everything from the centre, are learning that success depends on dispersing power and decisions away from the centre, there are some in the Community who seem to want to move in the opposite direction.&ldquoWe have not successfully rolled back the frontiers of the state in Britain, only to see them re-imposed at a European level with a European super-state exercising a new dominance from Brussels.&ldquoCertainly we want to see Europe more united and with a greater sense of common purpose.&ldquoBut it must be in a way which preserves the different traditions, parliamentary powers and sense of national pride in one's own country: for these have been the source of Europe's vitality through the centuries.Margaret Thatcher was in office from 1979 to 1990 (Image: )Margaret Thatcher hit out at John Major over his handling of the Maastricht Treaty (Image: )Just weeks later, she described the Community as &ldquosocialist in the Conservative Party conference &ndash&nbsptherefore marking a turning point that set Britain on the path to Brexit and established a genuine Tory eurosceptic wing.Thatcher was critical of Britain&rsquos relationship with Europe long after leaving office, too.She was furious about Sir John Major&rsquos decision to sign the Maastricht Treaty in 1992, saying: &ldquoOur trust was not well-founded.&ldquoWe got our fingers burnt. The most silly thing to do when you get your fingers burnt is to bring forward a bigger and worse Act which is the equivalent of putting your head in the fire.Speaking months later in the House of Lords about Maastricht, she added: &ldquoI could never have signed this treaty.

story: BBC journalist Laura Kuenssberg warned that MPs will have to wait until Christmas eve for a vote on the Brexit deal should an agreement be secured in December.EU leaders warned at the last Brussels summit that the November summit would be pushed back until &ldquodecisive progress has been made.BBC political editor Kuenssberg claimed a Brexit deal will be voted on by MPs on December 21, or even Christmas Eve.She said: &ldquoIf the deal is in December it looks like the vote would end up being Friday 21, but someone in Government told me today that there had been a discussion about whether or not it would be possible or not to have the final vote on Christmas eve. story: A Home Office investigation has been launched into claims a pupil is a 30-year-old man (Image: TWITTER)It's alleged his previous qualifications were not recognised in the UK and he was offered a place at the school after claiming to be a teenager.One parent, who did not want to be named, said: This is extremely concerning.He has told pupils he has had to lie to go get into high school to complete his GCSEs.Another parent, who also wished to remain anonymous, said: My son goes to the school and it is not a nice thought that this man is around children and sitting with them at lunch.An image taken on Snapchat by one pupil is believed to show the man dressed in uniform in a year 11 maths class.The text across the image reads: How is there a 30-year-old man in our maths class.It is understood the student in question would have gone through an age test, where they are asked questions about their past.The Home Office is now looking into the claims to establish the inidual and how he became enrolled at the school.A spokesman said: We do not routinely comment on inidual cases.The pupil accused of lying about his age is currently in year 11 after joining the school in September of this year.He is believed to be from Iran and speaks very little English.Stoke High School said the matter is being investigated (Image: Harry HubbardSWNS)                Macron urges EU to step up deportation of illegal immigrants                France cannot become &lsquoappeals court for migrants&rsquo warns Macron allyPupils claim teachers are unable to properly communicate with him due to the language barrier.But concerns have been raised that he is still studying at the school while investigations into his age are carried out.One mother, whose son is in the same year, said: Parents have been pulling their children out of school left right and centre.Looking at photos of this man, he is clearly older than 30. How can someone like this be eating with children, changing with children and learning with our children while pretending to be a teenager?He could be harmless but he could also be a dangerous man. I am terrified to think what would happen if he started a relationship with a young girl who thought he was her age.My son has always said that he looks older and he says the man does not even speak English. He sits in the class but cannot speak or learn.What makes it worse is that the school has made no contact with any of the parents or called us in for a meeting yet we are all up in arms and worried about our children's health and safety.Ofstead says Stoke High School needs improvement (Image: Ofsted)Something needs to be done and soon because this is likely to be happening all over the country and the Home Office is doing very little to help.Undocumented people are being let into our country and no tests are being done to find out their age.I won't have my son studying with a 30-year-old man.A statement from Stoke High School spokesman said: This is a matter for the Home Office. They are looking into this after we contacted them.We do not comment on inidual cases but we have followed government and local authority policies and guidance, as we do for any asylum admissions matter.The Ormiston Academies Trust issued a new statement today, saying that the pupil was not attending school at this time. The statement dropped a suggestion in the trust's previous statement which suggested that the pupil was an asylum seeker.The school takes on asylum seekers as required.Stoke High School is an co-educational academy in Ipswich, Suffolk with 668 pupils.The school which is rated &ldquorequires improvement by Ofsted gained Academy status in 2013.

title: brexit news latest backstop date chequers deal UK EU
story: A former EU judge accused the EU of being &ldquoinflexible over Brexit and believes they &ldquodo not set out the principal problems of the Irish border issue.Speaking to BBC, Professor Franklin Dehousse said: &ldquoYou see that there was flexibility and the question is, why has this flexibility completely disappeared now.&ldquoI suggest to many people on the EU side that they think very carefully about the political context they could create.Discussing whether the EU is trying to be flexible over changes made to the text of the Irish backstop, the International Law and Economics Professor said: &ldquoFirst I haven&rsquot seen the text but I read a lot of comments, they are trying to be flexible but they do not set out the principle problems. geographical indications, frankly I fail to understand why this and not copyright of patents for example.&ldquoIf you say I want a text about police co-operation for the future, on the Irish border, then why not.The interviewer then asked: &ldquoShould Article 50 be rewritten in future for the next country that leaves?Professor Dehousse laughed before replying: &ldquoI&rsquove been involved in all good news for Britain because the nation is still a &ldquomillion miles from a deal and the agreement would see London become the &ldquorule-taker.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab also arrived in parties.

title: Brexit news UK EU London Lord Mayor financial services Theresa May European Union
story: The Lord Mayor of London, Charles Bowman, said London is a &ldquounique financial services hub and revealed businesses are &ldquoquietly confident the capital will remain to be a leading financial services area after Brexit.Speaking to Bloomberg News, Mr Bowman said: &ldquoWe talk the B word, Brexit, but broadly speaking that is all about business. I will get the questions in relation to Brexit.&ldquoYes, they are keen to hear my sense of reassurance in relation to it but they are looking beyond.&ldquoThey are absolutely looking at business beyond &ndash whether that is in the spaces of innovation, FinTech, green finance or internationalisation of currencies, they are really focussed on the future.                Claims of Brexit deal on banking quashed by No10                BBC&rsquos Laura Kuenssberg makes RIDICULES EU position on Irish borderLord Mayor of LondonWhen quizzed about claims in which thousands of bankers will leave the capital as a result of Brexit, Mr Bowman said: &ldquoWe need to make sure that we get the appropriate deal but quietly confident, there is a sense of steely cut confidence.&ldquoI talk to business each and every day and what London possesses is something very unique through very many fundamentals. I think business does not want to move.&ldquoThey want to continue with the situation in London, the status of London as that preeminent hub for financial and professional services.Government sources claim British and&nbspEuropean Union&nbspnegotiators have reached a deal on all aspects on the future partnership on financial services and the exchange of data.Brexit news: Lord Mayor of London said businesses do not want to leave London after Brexit (Image: Bloomberg&bull)Under the agreement, UK financial services firms would be guaranteed access to European markets as long as British financial regulations remained aligned with Europe.In what would be considered a victory to the Prime Minister, reports said neither would be able to deny access to their markets without first consulting an independent arbitration panel and providing a notice period longer than the 30 days currently in place.But Mr Barnier warned Mrs May that the EU will never give up its right to autonomously deny access to its financial markets.Writing on Twitter, the EU negotiator said: &ldquoThe EU may grant and withdraw equivalence in some financial services autonomously.&ldquoAs with other third countries, EU is ready to have close regulatory dialogue with the UK in full respect for autonomy of both parties.

story: Lord Adonis lashed out at David Cameron over his political comeback hopes, accusing the former Prime Minister of &ldquobeing bored but was quickly reminded by radio host Nick Ferrari the former Prime Minister followed through on a promise to hold a referendum.&nbspThe Labour politician also criticised Mr Cameron&rsquos desire to become Foreign Secretary, calling it a &ldquoludicrous proposition.Speaking on LBC, Lord Adonis blasted: &ldquoHis record is one of disaster in Government.&ldquoI mean you have to go back to Lord North to have a Prime Minister that&rsquos left a country in a worse state because of a massive failed international project, which is what Brexit was. story: A yellow rain warning has been issued by the Met Office for this Saturday, alongside forecasts of a windy day widely across the UK.Met Office warned: &ldquoYELLOW WARNING OF RAIN for 'Central, Tayside &amp Fife', 'Grampian', 'Highlands &amp Eilean Siar', 'North West England', 'Strathclyde', 'SW Scotland, Lothian Borders&rsquo.&ldquoValid from 0000 GMT on Sat 03 November to 2359 GMT on Sat 03 November&ldquoHeavy and persistent rain lasting much of the day. BBC Weather: Britain braced for -5C FREEZING temperatures                End of the world FRENZY after mysterious society theories&ldquoBus and train services affected with journey times taking longer.The remnants of Hurricane Oscar are expected to bring gales and heavy rain to some parts on Saturday.BBC Weather presenter Darren Bett said: &ldquoSome wet and windy weather, heavy rain moving across western scotland, perhaps into Cumbria as well at times.This band of rain moves over the irish sea, just running into westernmost parts of England and Wales.BBC Weather: this weekend will bring gales and a rain warning for Saturday (Image: BBC)Still dry to south-east of UK, windy everywhere, gales are more likely over the Irish sea and into the western side of Scotland.BBC Weather forecaster Alina Jenkins also warned Storm Oscar will unleash strong winds across the UK on Saturday.The meteorologist said: &ldquoThose winds will be picking up further overnight, all tied in with this area of low pressure.&ldquoIt was Hurricane Oscar, no longer a hurricane but it will bring some strong winds, particularly to Northern Ireland, northwest England and Scotland through Saturday.Here we will see outbreaks of rain slowly trying to slide their way eastwards eventually affecting western fringes of Wales and southwest England towards the afternoon.Sunday will be a rather mild day, with lower winds. title: ufo proof aliens life on mars nasa ufo sightings alien news space extraterrestrial
story: UFO proof? Hovering rock on Mars &lsquoremnants of an alien aircraft or spacecraft' (Image: )The rock was picked up by images from NASA&rsquos rovers on the Red Planet, prompting speculation from alien hunters.It looks as if the rock is hovering above the ground of Mars, casting a dark shadow over the surface as it does.Conspiracy theorists quickly picked up on the image, claiming that it is proof that a once highly advanced species either existed or visited Mars in the distant past.The image was picked up by prominent alien hunter Scott C Waring.                Alien hunters find &lsquoCITY on Mars&rsquo as Nasa pictures show CARS                Alien on Mars: NASA photos of &lsquoaliens&rsquo on Mars spark UFO claimsMr Waring wrote on his website UFO Sightings Daily: &ldquoNow here is something you don't see everyday. I found a hovering rock on the surface of Mars in a NASA photo.&ldquoThe thick rectangle shaped rock has a rectangle shape shadow below it. The object is about 10-12 inches from the surface, just hovering in place.&ldquoThis could indicate that this is some ancient technology, not a mere rock after all.&ldquoStill filled with power, still hovering on its own, even though the rest of its craft no longer exists.&ldquoProbably remnants of an alien aircraft or spacecraft of long ago.However, sceptics and NASA would say the hovering rock and other similar findings are just the effects of pareidolia &ndash a psychological phenomenon when the brain tricks the eyes into seeing familiar objects or shapes in patterns or textures such as a rock surface.This is not the first time that evidence of aliens on Mars has allegedly been discovered.Earlier this year, an alien face was found in a NASA satellite image of Mars, according to more bonkers claims.Mr Waring was convinced it could be a rock carving, done by a Martian race, in the same way ancient Britons carved out the chalk figures in hillsides like the giant of Cerene Abbas in Dorset and the Long Man of Wilmington in East Sussex.This could indicate that this is some ancient technology, not a mere rock after all (Image: NASA)However, NASA insisted the rock is just a meteorite impact crater that has been left in the unusual form by later erosion.When NASA released the image under the alien head caption, it said: The image shows an impact crater in Chryse Planitia, not too far from the Viking 1 lander site, that to seems to resemble a bug-eyed head.The two odd depressions at the north end of the crater (the &lsquoeyes&rsquo) may have formed by wind or water erosion.This region has been modified by both processes, with water action occurring in the distant past via floods that poured across western Chryse Planitia from Maja Valles, and wind action common occurrence in more recent history.

story: Mr Demesmaeker revealed he had questioned whether Emmanuel Macron's political experiment in France would be sustainable in the long-term since his election.He suggested the French President struggled to transform the expectations he fuelled during the electoral campaign into reality.Speaking to Raw Politics, the Belgian MEP said: His political movement &ndash which rose out of nothing, it grew like a mushroom, without any political structure behind them &ndash I was wondering from the beginning if this is a sustainable political project, party or is it going to disappear very very soon?He has created a lot of expectations, a lot of hopes with people and, of course, between dream and reality there&rsquos a big difference.                Demands for France to TURN AGAINST EU to force out Europhile President                FRANCE RIOTS: Gangs of masked youths on RAMPAGE in night of violenceMr Macron saw his approval rating nosee at the end of October, with only 26 percent of French people now saying they support him and his policies.According to poll data published on Wednesday by Kantar Public, 71 percent of those surveyed said they had no confidence in the President&rsquos ability to run the country.Mr&nbspDemesmaeker suggested the unclear reshuffle of his Cabinet cost Mr Macron support from the public: You&rsquove had this problem within his Cabinet &ndash with heavyweight ministers leaving &ndash in circumstances not always very clear to everybody. So yes, he&rsquos been in trouble.Three members of Cabinet, including Interior Minister Gerard Collomb, turned in their resignation between August and October. Environment minister Nicolas Hulot surprised the President as he announced he would quit during a live radio show.&nbspFrance news: Mr Macron suffered a four-point drop in support in October (Image: &bullEURONEWS)The resignations forced Mr Macron into instigating a Cabinet reshuffle which attracted further criticism but despite his rapidly falling approval, the 40-year-old leader has taken some time off.Government spokesman Benjamin Griveaux said: &ldquoLike millions of French people, it can happen that the President of the Republic takes a few days off.&ldquoFor several days, friends have been urging him to rest, eat better and sleep better, but also to stop trying to control government life in the early hours of the night.The French President, who was elected in May 2017, was seen as a reformer and an alternative to the polarising campaigns from the left and the right.                MACRON BURNOUT: Rumours swirl as French president cancels cabinetFrench citizens have repeatedly accused Mr Macron of being out of touch with the average person and have dubbed him the &ldquopresident of the rich.His image was not helped by several political blunders, such as dismissing an unemployed man&rsquos problems in a video that went viral.Meanwhile, it was also revealed he has spent around &pound23,000 on make-up in the first three months in the &Eacutelys&eacutee Palace, as well as ordering 1,200 plates worth hundreds of thousands of euros.More than 100,000 protestors took to the streets at the beginning of October to oppose new economic policies that would see some people suffering cuts to their monthly support.Leaders on the left have accused Macron of &ldquodestroying France&rsquos social model and labour unions are planning more demonstrations.Prime Minister Edouard Philippe also saw confidence in his leadership fall by 3 percentage points, with 64 percent saying they had no confidence in him.

title: bhai dooj 2018 diwali festival
story: But what is it, how is it connected to Diwali, and why is it celebrated Bhai Dooj is a Hindu celebration of brotherly-sisterly love.There are two celebrations of this special sibling relationship every year. The other is called Raksha Bandhan.The word Dooj means the second day after the new moon, while Bhai means brother.Legend says that, on this day, the Lord of Death Yamaraj visited his sister Yami, who put the auspicious tikaon her brothers forehead.The tika can also be known as a tilak or tilaka.Hindus believe that any boy who receives a tika from his sister on this day will never be sent to hell.According to another story, Lord Krishna visited his sister Subhadra on this day, after slaying the Narakasura demon.She is said to have welcomed him with the holy lamp, flowers, and sweets and put the same protective spot on her brothers forehead.Women are revered during Bhai Dooj.Bhai Dooj is celebrated on the fth and last day of Diwali.In , that puts it on Friday, November .The main celebration of Diwali is on November .On Bhai Dooj, girls are supposed to show their love by putting an auspicious tika or vermilion mark on their brothers forehead.They should also perform the ritual of aarti by lighting a holy flame - as a mark of love and protection from evil forces.In , sisters are lavished with presents and blessings from their brothers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: In a victory for The Sun, Philip Hammond will today announce a commemorative Brexit p coin, available from March , , to mark the moment we leave the EU.It will have the Queen’s head on one side and the phrase “Friendship with all nations” on the other — exactly the type of positive, outward-looking message we want to send.Despite the Remain naysayers’ claims, Britain remains a top global financial, diplomatic and military power.Unshackled from the EU, we will boom as a global business hub by developing new relationships.Despite the Government’s commemorative move, the Royal Mail refuses to release a Brexit stamp, claiming our exit will not be “an important anniversary”. title: latest telethon shows us once and for all that c4s just a load of cake and balls
story: You watch BBC’s Children In Need, you’re getting Clare Balding, Doctor Who and dancers, whether you like it or not.ITV  It’d take sniper fire or a dinner setting next to Sir Phillip Green before Cowell was a no-show.Channel , though Apart from a bit of a secondhand cake-baking and Gogglebox, I was drawing a blank before Friday night.So it was with a mix of fascination and dread that I tuned into Stand Up To Cancer. A seven-hour slog live from Westminster City Hall, presented by Adam Hills, Maya Jama and the network’s spare part Alan Carr, who set the tone for most of what followed interviewing Foxy from SAS: Who Dares Wins.“It’s been announced you’ve got a new Stand Up To Cancer series starting next year. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. title: mass dig of 60000 skeletons from 230 year old cemetery set to expose londons secrets
story: The bones of , people have so far been exhumed from the burial ground near Euston Station to make way for the new high speed railway between the capital and Birmingham.Recently released photos of the major dig show archaeologists clearing thick clay from coffins and brushing dirt from remains.They are part of an archaeological team currently delving into , years of British history along the -mile HS route.Land at St James’s Gardens – the former site of a late th and th century burial ground – is needed for Euston’s expansion.With tens of thousands of skeletons to be removed, protests and a memorial service have been held at the site where people were laid to rest from  to .HS project bosses say that an estimated , people are buried there, including notable people such as Lord George Gordon, who in  called for the repeal of the Catholic Relief Act and ato the repression of Catholics.He led a ,-strong crowd from St George’s Fields to the Houses of Parliament, which prompted anti-Catholic riots.Also buried at St James’s Garden is Matthew Flinders, one of the world’s most accomplished navigators who was born in England, entered the navy at the age of  and served with Captain Bligh.After sailing for Australia just five years later, he made detailed surveys of the country’s coastline and islands – becoming the first person to circumnavigate it.Machines have been used to remove the topsoil, stopping once coffins or human remains are exposed. Archaeologists then carry out further excavation by hand.HS bosses said that “all artefacts and human remains will be treated with due dignity, care and respect.”They have been working with Historic England, the Church of England and the local parish to “put appropriate plans in place for reburial”.A London Inheritance said that it was “unusual for a public park and an old burial ground to disappear, however this has been the fate of St James’s Gardens.“It will be a major task for the exhumation and reburial of such a large number of bodies.”The website has photos of the gardens, to record “a historic space that will soon be lost from the landscape of London forever.”Research will be carried out into how cemeteries have developed, and the burial practice in terms of the treatment on its own is unlikely to provide signicant insights.”So far, sites along the rail route have revealed Neolithic tools, medieval pottery and Victorian time capsules.In total, more than a thousand archaeologists are set to explore more than  separate sites, from prehistoric and Roman settlements to those from the Industrial Revolution and the Second World War.Mark Thurston, HS chief executive, said: Before we bore the tunnels, lay the tracks and build the stations, an unprecedented amount of archaeological research is now taking place between London and Birmingham.This is the largest archaeological exploration ever in Britain, employing a record number of skilled archaeologists and heritage specialists from across the UK and beyond.Archaeological sites being investigated along the route include a prehistoric hunter-gatherer site on the outskirts of London, a Roman British town in Fleet Marston, Aylesbury, a ,-year-old demolished medieval church and burial ground in title: new book reveals the best ways to keep your home safe from burglars
story: Sophie Hannah wrote A Dark Time to pass on security hints and tips to homeowners who find themselves at increased risk of burglary during the winter months.Seven homes in the UK are burgled every minute across a calendar year.A study of , homeowners carried out by a home security firm to coincide with the launch of the book found  per cent of Brits have no security measures in place whatsoever.A Dark Time is the latest entry in Hannah’s Waterhouse and Zailer series, which started in  with the release of Little Face, which sold over , copies in the UK.Sophie Hannah said: “I’ve really loved writing A Dark Time.I had an idea that Id really wanted to try out for ages – and raising awareness around the increased risks to home security now that the nights are getting darker was the perfect fit for executing it.My story idea needed exactly that setting, a dark night, and involved a burglary of a very peculiar kind – a puzzle that I knew my detectives Simon Waterhouse and Charlie Zailer would enjoy solving.UK homes are at an elevated risk of burglary thanks to the clocks going back, according to research.December was revealed as the peak time for break-ins across the UK, with  per cent of Brits experiencing a burglary in the last year alone.And six in  Brits feel more vulnerable to a break-in when the nights grow longer.However, keeping our homes warm and making sure energy bills are paid are the nation’s top concerns after the clocks go back – ahead of securing our castles.Nearly a quarter of Brits have fitted a security alarm to warn off potential intruders, and  per cent keep their house lights on to make it look like someone is home.A further  per cent close their blinds or curtains while they’re out, and just under a tenth have bought a dog to deter burglars from targeting their property.Lee Jasper, security expert at ADT said: “Year on year, we have seen a  per cent increase in burglaries during the darker months.So it’s vital that people put the right security measures in place to help protect their homes to avoid falling victim.“The research shows we’re feeling more vulnerable as a nation when the clocks go back, however there is a clear lack of awareness when it comes down to preventing burglaries.“We’re hoping that the launch of A Dark Time can help the nation safeguard their homes, in an entertaining and engaging way.”A Dark Time is available as a free download from the ADT website from Monday nd October on: https:www.adt adarktime

title: ww1 veterans the last tommies bbc four interviews
story: Survivors of the First World War will tell their personal tales of battles and bravery ahead of the centenary celebrations of the armistice agreement which ended the war on  November .One of the veterans recalled: You could feel the machine gun bullets flying past you - you had to keep on going.And another, Tommy Gay, told his story of the Battle of the Somme, in which , British troops were lost in a single day.Gay was just  at the time of the battle because he lied about his age to be conscripted.He said: I was one of the first to go up over the top - we met a hurricane of bullets.Some of the chaps were lying around with their arms off in pain.You couldnt help the poor souls... You couldnt help them at all.Another soldier remembered: We were able to see the infantry going forwards.In some cases they didnt get very far - they were just wiped out.The incredible accounts will be broadcast as part of a new BBC Four series titled WWI: The Last Tommies.And although the last surviving Tommy - Harry Patch - died nine years ago at the age of , the new programme contains never-before-seen interviews with Tommies recorded over the last  years while World War One was still within living memory.The amazing interviews are accompanied by digitally restored archive footage shot on the fronts and at home during the First World War.The first episode covers the early years of the war, in which the Pals Battalions went off to the front for the first time, while the second hears tells of the Somme.The third and final episode covers the Battle of Passchendaele in  - a battle fought in a quagmire of mud at a terrible cost to soldiers lives.It also discusses the unimaginable emotional tragedy of the war at home in Britain as the nation came to terms with the horror of the war.The series WWI: The Last Tommies will be broadcast on pm - pm Monday  November to Wednesday  November on BBC Four.

title: kiana smith purple birthmark covers face surgery
story: Kiana Smith, , was born with a port-wine stain birthmark on the left side of her face.The purple pigmentation also covered her neck and chest and left her the victim of cruel taunts during her school years.But Kiana, from Cumana in Trinidad, has undergone five surgeries and specialised laser treatment to help lessen then mark and is now an ambassador for the Vascular Birthmark Foundation.She has recently flown to New York for more treatment, but is concerned she can feel the mark growing back.I’m feeling some bulkiness along here with my chin and underneath a little bit, she told Barcroft TV.“The surgeries on my birthmark have helped so much. I don’t have this bulk on my face anymore.“As I would describe it, it’s like having this huge one-inch steak, the weight of it hanging on your face.“Sometimes I would feel the blood just running and pumping in my birthmark.“But I don’t have that anymore. I am able to speak much better which is fantastic. “A port-wine stain birthmark are called so because they look like someone has spilt port-wine on the skin.About  out of every , children are born with these marks.They most often occur on faces, heads, arms or legs and are caused by abnormal development of blood vessels in the skin.Unlike other birthmarks port-wine stains do not fade as a child gets older, instead it grows with them and often becomes hardened on the outside with age.But Kiana also have a genetic condition that causes her birthmark to overgrow.At one point it was so large she found it dficult to eat and drink.It is something that will always be there, always growing.“The birthmark will never go away. I have accepted that now.“I don’t want my whole le focused on the fact that I have a birthmark.“I don’t want it to keep me back from enjoying le.”Despite finally learning to accept the way she looks, Kiana said she will never get used to strangers staring at her.“People always stare at me when I leave the house,” she added.“I also feel like I have been in dficult situations with children.“You know children will often freak out, screaming, crying and everything and I have felt so bad because I’m the cause of their reaction.“I think entering high school was when I really had those first confidence issues“I would get called, ‘prune face’, ‘purple face’ and one of the popular ones was the ‘purple people eater’.“But my mother really helped me deal with this by treating me just as any other child.”Mum Ann McCarthy, , added: “I don’t think it affects her as much now as an adult as it did when she was much younger.“She’s able to be in society as a human being and like a normal human being.“I’ve always tried to emphasise to her, it is what is inside you that matters – not your external appearance.“I am unable to really say in words how proud I am of her.”But Kiana said all of the name-calling she faced earlier in le has only made her more determined to succeed.“I don’t really know what the future holds,” she said.“In terms of my birthmark, I’d like to have more laser surgery because that is critical.“I’m not going to say that I’ll ever be perfectly happy with my birthmark, because I don’t love it.“Despite everything, I am proud of myself and what I have achieved.”

title: newlywed woman doctor groin maggot inside her
story: The -year-old finally sought medical help after developing a red blister-like mark on her inner leg around two months after her honeymoon in Belize.The unnamed woman, from Tampa, Florida, was given antibiotics after visiting her GP but failed to see any improvements in her condition.She then decided to go to Tampa General Hospital, where the mark left doctors dumbfounded.Some speculated that the mark may have been a cyst while others contemplated it being an ingrown hair.Still unsatisfied with their answers, she decided to visit the Tampa’s Memorial Hospital where the horric truth finally wriggled out.Dr Enrico Camporesi noticed the skin around the sore had become hard, and decided to investigatethere may be an egg or bean beneath the surface.It was only after he consulted with a surgeon that the pair discovered the mark was in fact a live creature.The unnamed woman was immediately given local anaesthetic and surgeons got to work removing what turned out to be a maggot, known as a human botfly larva.The woman’s sore healed within a week and she was finally relieved of her constant groin itch.Her weird case has also been listed in the Journal of Investigative Medicine High Impact Case Reports.According to the medical journal’s authors, people who have been infected with the same type of maggot will often feel the creature wriggling around under the skin when they shower or attempt to cover the wound up.If left untreated, the adult larva will usually fall out of the skin within six weeks of infection, before maturing into an adult botfly.While the tiny creature is rare in the United States, it is extremely common in the Tropics.The botfly larva can easily be killed by taking away its air supply by putting Vaseline or similar on the skin where the lump is.But the larva will still need to be extracted from the human body.Adult botflies have non-al mouth parts and do not feed.

title: leicester city fans love vichai for his deeds not his words
story: And then, just as we were getting used to Raksriaksorn, it changed again to something even more unpronounceable. Srivaddhanaprabha - a title bestowed on the -year-old entrepreneur by the Thai royal family, in recognition of his success and philanthropy.Its hard to form a close bond with someone whose name you cant pronounce and have to Google to spell. But we did that at Leicester City Football Club. We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha.We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha not just for who he was - but because of who he wasnt.We loved him not only for what he did - but what he didnt do. The footballing landscape has been ruined by owners who take clubs as playthings, get bored and run them into the ground. You dont need me to tell you who they are. We all know.We knew the dference, at Leicester City Football Club, between good owners and bad ones.Wed lived through the alternative.Wed had owners who didnt care.Wed had owners who couldnt club together the #, needed to buy a former midfield favourite who wanted toto the club. This wasnt the s. It was just over a decade ago.Wed had owners whose grip on the LCFC purse string was so careless it plunged the club into administration.Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha was not like that. When he arrived at Leicester in the summer of , he bought the club from Milan Mandaric. There was concern in some quarters that because Mandaric had sealed the deal then maybe this new Thai chap was cut from the same cloth.He wasnt.If Mandaric was all about hiring and firing and shooting from the hip in pt back page headlines - and, oh boy, he was - then Khun Vichai, to give him his conventional Thai title, was the opposite of that. I was a feature writer at the Leicester Mercury when Vichai arrived. I did all sorts of features about Leicester City during my time there. I never interviewed him. Few people did.He didnt do many interviews. He didnt want to and he didnt have to. So he didnt. He preferred to do what he had to do and stay, unnoticed, in the background.
